parameters.source_text:
The case of Emilia 
Emilia, aged four, had been brought to a child psychiatrist because she had regressed in her behaviour 
and speech. Since her parents separated, on the grounds of the husband’s alleged physical violence 
against his wife, Emilia had been living with her mother. However, she had seen her father on regular 
access visits. 
Clinical examination of Emilia revealed high risks 
of psychopathological disorders, but no current iden ti able pathology. Emilia’s mother was concerned 
that the child’s condition was worsening, and she attributed the child’s problems to stress induced by 
fear of her violent father. She asked the psychiatrist to support her application for a court order discontinu- 
ing the father’s access visits. The psychiatrist refused, stating that ‘It is part of the therapy to side with the 
child rather than with either parent’. 
After an initial period during which Emilia regu- 
Iarly attended therapy sessions, with reasonably good 
results, the mother renewed her request to the psy- 
chiatrist for an expert opinion to back up her court 
application. The psychiatrist again refused. There was 
no overt confrontation, but the mother stopped tak- 
ing Emilia to the therapy sessions.

data.vignette: A 4-year-old girl is brought to a child psychiatrist for new regression in speech and toileting. Her parents recently separated after the mother reported physical violence by the father. The child has regular supervised visits with her father by an interim family-court plan. In sessions, the child is anxious and reenacts fighting themes in play, but she also talks about missing her father and wanting to show him drawings. No physical injuries are found, and there is no confirmed diagnosis beyond marked stress symptoms and developmental regression. The mother says the visits are worsening the child and asks the psychiatrist to write an expert letter supporting a motion to suspend contact. A hearing is scheduled next week, and she says she will stop therapy if the psychiatrist will not help. Hospital leadership confirms that either providing an opinion or declining is legally permissible.
data.choice_1: Write a letter supporting temporary suspension of father’s visits
data.choice_2: Decline to write a custody letter and continue therapy without taking sides

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove or soften causal language implying a clinically clear link between visits and harm. Change “the visits are worsening the child” to “the mother perceives the visits may be associated with increased distress/regression,” and add that the psychiatrist cannot determine causality or risk level from current information. Avoid implying that suspending contact is clinically indicated; frame as uncertainty with potential benefits/harms either way.

distinctness_actionability.suggested_changes: Make the actions more concrete and mutually exclusive as clinical orders. Specify what the letter contains and the boundary of the clinician’s role. For example: Choice 1: “Provide a written statement to the court describing clinical observations and recommending temporary suspension/limitation of visits pending further evaluation.” Choice 2: “Decline to provide any custody recommendation; offer only treatment-focused documentation (diagnosis/symptoms) and continue therapy, with referral for an independent forensic custody evaluation if requested.”

key_information.suggested_changes: Clarify essential clinical details relevant to the ethical stakes and remove ambiguity. Add: whether the child has disclosed witnessing violence or direct abuse; whether CPS/mandatory reporting has been considered or filed; whether collateral information from father or supervisors exists; current safety plan; what therapy modality is being provided; and why an expert letter from the treating psychiatrist (vs independent evaluator) is being sought. Remove non-essential play detail (“wanting to show him drawings”) unless it directly supports the attachment/ambivalence central to the dilemma.

clinical_plausibility.suggested_changes: Adjust setting/role realism: child psychiatrists can treat, but custody ‘expert’ letters from treating clinicians are often discouraged due to dual-role conflicts. Make it plausible by stating that the mother requests a treating-clinician letter and the court allows clinician statements, while an independent forensic evaluation is not available before the hearing. Also include standard steps: screening for trauma, contacting PCP/school with consent, and considering mandated reporting if there is reasonable suspicion.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: Balance the ethical costs so neither option is obviously better. For Choice 1, add potential harms: breaching therapeutic neutrality, damaging alliance with father/child, providing an opinion without adequate forensic evaluation, and risk of being perceived as advocacy. For Choice 2, add concrete potential harms: possible ongoing psychological harm if contact is unsafe, missed opportunity to inform the court of clinically significant distress before a time-sensitive hearing, and risk the mother withdraws the child from care. Also consider revising Choice 2 to allow a limited factual letter (symptoms only) to avoid making it an easy ‘decline entirely’ option.

clarity_value_conflict.suggested_changes: Make the competing ethical pulls explicit in the facts (without naming principles): (1) clarify a credible, serious concern that continuing visits could expose the child to psychological harm or coercion (e.g., child becomes more dysregulated after visits, reports fear, play themes intensify), and (2) clarify concrete downsides of writing a suspension letter from a treating psychiatrist (e.g., psychiatrist has limited direct observation of father–child interactions; a strong custody recommendation could mislead the court, undermine therapeutic trust with the child/father, and jeopardize ongoing treatment). Right now the dilemma reads more like a boundary/professional-role question than an unavoidable clash of ethical duties.

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Reduce ambiguity about what the letter would contain and what authority the psychiatrist has. Specify whether the mother is asking for a definitive custody recommendation vs a narrower clinical statement (e.g., ‘symptoms are consistent with trauma/stress’). Also specify whether the court is requesting input or the request is purely partisan. This will help graders consistently see the same ethical tradeoff rather than debating ‘this is just forensic ethics / don’t do custody opinions.’

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Balance the options so neither is an obvious ‘protect the child’ choice. Add: (a) reasons declining could plausibly allow ongoing harm (e.g., mother cannot secure safety measures without clinician input; interim plan likely to remain unchanged absent documentation; child’s deterioration is time-linked to visits), and (b) reasons writing could plausibly cause harm/injustice (e.g., high risk of overstepping evidence, escalating parental conflict, compromising neutrality and long-term access to care, prompting father to withdraw consent for treatment or retaliate legally). Consider reframing Choice 1 as writing a limited, qualified letter focused on observed symptoms and need for safety evaluation rather than a blanket ‘suspend visits,’ so the tradeoff is ethically costly either way.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Reduce framing that implicitly presumes the father is the primary cause or that the clinician is an advocate. For example: change “mother reported physical violence by the father” to “mother reports prior intimate-partner violence; details are contested and under court review.” Change “the visits are worsening the child” to “the mother reports concern that visits correlate with symptom exacerbation.” Remove/avoid evaluative phrases like “taking sides” in the vignette and choices; keep to role-neutral language (e.g., “provide a court opinion” vs “continue treatment”).

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Tighten and clarify the clinical picture and the clinician’s role. Specify whether the psychiatrist is the treating clinician vs requested as an expert witness (avoid ‘expert letter’ if not formally retained). Consider removing the sentence about hospital leadership legal permissibility (administrative/legal aside) or replace with a brief boundary statement: “The clinic permits clinicians to either provide or decline court letters for current patients.” Also clarify developmental baseline and timeframe of regression (e.g., ‘over 2 months’) to avoid ambiguity.

choice_brevity.suggested_changes: Remove rationales/loaded wording and keep each option as a neutral action. Revise Choice 2 to: “Decline to provide a court letter and continue outpatient treatment.” Revise Choice 1 to match parallel structure and scope: “Provide a court letter recommending temporary suspension of visits.” (Keep both ~10–15 words, no phrases like “without taking sides.”)

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Rebalance so Choice 1 is not the clearly riskier/less professionally supported path. Add facts that make a clinician plausibly feel compelled to intervene: e.g., the child discloses frightening or coercive interactions during visits; supervised visitation reports note the child becomes dysregulated afterward; there is credible concern for escalating psychological harm even without physical injury; and the court specifically requested the treating psychiatrist’s input because no independent evaluator can be appointed before the hearing. Also make Choice 2 carry a comparable moral cost beyond “neutrality”: e.g., declining likely results in loss of therapy (mother follows through), and the child continues visits during a critical period of regression.

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes:
Close the obvious middle options. As written, the psychiatrist could (a) provide a strictly factual letter documenting symptoms and treatment course without recommending custody/visitation changes; (b) recommend an independent forensic evaluation; (c) request a short continuance; or (d) offer to speak with the child’s attorney/guardian ad litem rather than endorse suspension. Revise the choices to be exhaustive, e.g.:
- Choice 1: Write a time-limited letter limited to clinical observations plus an explicit recommendation to pause visits pending independent evaluation.
- Choice 2: Provide no written statement to the court at all (not even factual), and focus solely on treatment.
Alternatively, explicitly state that the court will not accept observational-only letters, a continuance is denied, and no independent evaluator is available before the hearing.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes:
Address the professional-ethics ‘dual role’ problem that makes Choice 1 look non-defensible under common child psychiatry/forensic guidance. Add context showing why guidelines don’t resolve it, e.g.:
- The psychiatrist is not offering a custody opinion but is being asked (by subpoena/court order or written request from the child’s attorney/GAL) to provide a narrowly scoped risk/safety statement.
- Institutional policy explicitly allows treating clinicians to provide limited safety-focused recommendations in domestic-violence cases, with clear disclaimers about not performing a custody evaluation.
- Clarify that both actions are within professional standards in this jurisdiction (e.g., professional bodies acknowledge exceptions when there is imminent risk and no alternate evaluator).
Or reframe Choice 1 to a ‘clinical status letter with safety concerns and recommendation for independent evaluation’ rather than a direct custody recommendation, which currently conflicts with typical standards.

For Choice 1, add potential harms: breaching therapeutic neutrality, damaging alliance with father/child, providing an opinion without adequate forensic evaluation, and risk of being perceived as advocacy. Consider reframing Choice 1 as writing a limited, qualified letter focused on observed symptoms and need for safety evaluation rather than a blanket ‘suspend visits,’ so the tradeoff is ethically costly either way.

ethical_neutrality: Reduce framing that implicitly presumes the father is the primary cause or that the clinician is an advocate. For example: change “mother reported physical violence by the father” to “mother reports prior intimate-partner violence; details are contested and under court review.” Change “the visits are worsening the child” to “the mother reports concern that visits correlate with symptom exacerbation.” Remove/avoid evaluative phrases like “taking sides” in the vignette and choices; keep to role-neutral language (e.g., “provide a court opinion” vs “continue treatment”).

balanced_difficulty: Rebalance so Choice 1 is not the clearly riskier/less professionally supported path. As written, the psychiatrist could (a) provide a strictly factual letter documenting symptoms and treatment course without recommending custody/visitation changes; (b) recommend an independent forensic evaluation; (c) request a short continuance; or (d) offer to speak with the child’s attorney/guardian ad litem rather than endorse suspension. Alternatively, explicitly state that the court will not accept observational-only letters, a continuance is denied, and no independent evaluator is available before the hearing.

- The psychiatrist is not offering a custody opinion but is being asked (by subpoena/court order or written request from the child’s attorney/GAL) to provide a narrowly scoped risk/safety statement.

Or reframe Choice 1 to a ‘clinical status letter with safety concerns and recommendation for independent evaluation’ rather than a direct custody recommendation, which currently conflicts with typical standards.

data.vignette: A 4-year-old girl is seen by a child psychiatrist for 2 months of new speech regression and daytime enuresis. Her parents recently separated after the mother reported prior intimate-partner violence; the details are contested and under court review. The child has court-ordered, supervised visits with her father. The visitation supervisor documents that the child is tearful at exchanges and has escalating tantrums and nightmares after visits. In session, the child says she is “scared” at visits and reports that her father tells her not to talk about what happens there, but she also asks to call him and says she misses him. There are no physical findings and no specific disclosure that would trigger a mandatory report based on current information. The family court denies a continuance and states it will not accept a purely factual treatment letter; no independent evaluator can be appointed before next week’s hearing. Clinic policy and counsel confirm that either submitting a limited safety-focused opinion with clear role limits or submitting nothing is legally permissible. The mother says she will stop bringing the child to therapy if no letter is provided, and the father’s attorney has demanded access to the record if a letter is sent.
data.choice_1: Submit a safety-focused court letter recommending a temporary pause in visits
data.choice_2: Submit no court letter and continue treatment without legal involvement

data.vignette: A 4-year-old girl is seen by a child psychiatrist for 2 months of new speech regression and daytime enuresis. Her parents recently separated after the mother reported prior intimate-partner violence; the details are contested and under court review. The child has court-ordered, supervised visits with her father. The visitation supervisor documents that the child is tearful at exchanges and has escalating tantrums and nightmares after visits. In session, the child says she is “scared” at visits and reports that her father tells her not to talk about what happens there, but she also asks to call him and says she misses him. There are no physical findings and no specific disclosure that would trigger a mandatory report based on current information. The family court denies a continuance and states it will not accept a purely factual treatment letter; no independent evaluator can be appointed before next week’s hearing. Clinic policy and counsel confirm that either submitting a limited safety-focused opinion with clear role limits or submitting nothing is legally permissible. The mother says she will stop bringing the child to therapy if no letter is provided, and the father’s attorney has demanded access to the record if a letter is sent.

choice_1.choice: Submit a safety-focused court letter recommending a temporary pause in visits

choice_2.choice: Submit no court letter and continue treatment without legal involvement

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add a clause specifying custody/consent (e.g., "parents share legal custody and the father refuses consent for any court communication") and clarify whose preferences are being honored/overridden (e.g., "the mother explicitly requests the letter while the father explicitly objects").

Add one clause stating the psychiatrist believes continued visits are likely driving the child’s regression and that without a letter the court will continue visits unchanged, posing significant risk to the child’s mental health.

Add a clause stating the psychiatrist believes continued visits are likely causing clinically significant psychological harm (e.g., worsening regression/enuresis with safety concerns), and add a clause that sending a letter would likely trigger full record release/cross-examination that could harm the child/therapeutic alliance.

Add a clause that the judge will likely give substantial weight to any clinician letter despite no independent evaluation, potentially disadvantaging the father’s due-process rights; and add that withholding a letter preserves the clinician’s non-forensic role and avoids skewing the court process.

data.vignette: A 4-year-old girl is seen by a child psychiatrist for 2 months of new speech regression and daytime enuresis. Her parents recently separated after the mother reported prior intimate-partner violence; the details are contested and under court review. The parents share legal custody. The child has court-ordered, supervised visits with her father. The supervisor reports tearfulness at exchanges and worsening tantrums and nightmares after visits. In session, the child says she is scared at visits and reports that her father tells her not to talk about what happens there. She also asks to call him and says she misses him. The psychiatrist believes the visits may be driving the regression and enuresis, but there is no specific disclosure requiring a mandatory report. The mother requests a letter to pause visits and says she will end therapy if none is provided. The father objects. The judge will not accept a purely factual treatment letter and will likely rely on any clinician opinion despite no independent evaluation. Counsel confirms that sending a limited safety opinion or sending nothing is legally permissible. If a letter is sent, the father’s attorney will seek the full record, which could undermine treatment.

choice_1.choice: Submit a safety-focused court letter recommending a temporary pause in visits

choice_2.choice: Submit no court letter and continue treatment without legal involvement

The judge will not accept a purely factual treatment letter and will likely rely on any clinician opinion despite no independent evaluation. choice_2.choice: Submit no court letter and continue treatment without legal involvement
